title: 110_s2812
content: The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the Act, increases the types of originating sites and expands the practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. It also improves the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands the types of originating sites eligible for telehealth services, including skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, mental health centers, and other sites with a telecommunications system. It also eliminates facility fees for certain originating sites. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands originating sites eligible for telehealth services, eliminating facility fees for specific sites. Amendments include no facility fee for certain originating sites, effective 90 days after enactment. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF PRACTITIONERS ELIGIBLE TO FURNISH TELEHEALTH SERVICES. Expansion of practitioners eligible to furnish telehealth services under Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act includes physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, and certified providers. The expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services under Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act includes physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, certified providers, and other individuals or entities deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The amendments made by this section will apply to services rendered 90 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Improvement of process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Telehealth Advisory Committee will provide recommendations to the Secretary on adding or deleting services and HCPCS codes. If the Secretary does not implement a recommendation, they must publish a statement in the Federal Register explaining why. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, consists of 7 members including practicing physicians and non-physician healthcare providers. They make recommendations on services and HCPCS codes for authorized payment under the Social Security Act. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, consists of 7 members including practicing physicians and non-physician healthcare providers. Members must have experience in telemedicine or telehealth, with preference given to those currently providing services. The Committee's composition should reflect a balance of specialties and geographic regions, taking into account stakeholder recommendations. The Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, must have a balanced representation of specialties and geographic regions. Members serve terms specified by the Secretary, meet twice a year, and can convene as needed. The Committee is exempt from certain regulations and administrative limitations.
